sentence: We reviewed the first 321 results of the sorted list to eventually identify the 50 articles that pertained to the meniscal criteria (Figure 1).

There was a moderate and statistically significant positive correlation between year of publication and citation density (r = 0.625; P < .001), and little correlation with no statistical significance was found between year of publication and raw citation count (r = 0.241; P = .10) (Figure 2).
All articles were published between 1975 and 2013 (Figure 3), with most of the articles being published between 2000 to 2010 (n = 25 articles) and 1990 to 1999 (15 articles).

Modified PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) diagram detailing the collection of the top 50 most cited articles pertaining to meniscus injury.Figure 2.

Open in a new tab
Correlation of the year of publication and citation density (r = 0.625; P < .001).Figure 3.

The majority of articles were published in The American Journal of Sports Medicine (AJSM), with 9 papers (18%), followed by Arthritis & Rheumatology and the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (JBJS; also known as the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery–American Volume), with 7 (14%) and 6 (12%) articles, respectively (Figure 4).

Open in a new tab
Number of publications per journal.Most articles had a clinical science and outcome focus (n = 26; 52%), followed by basic science (n = 16; 32%), with only 6 (12%) reviews or meta-analyses (Figure 5).

Open in a new tab
Type of study, with the majority being related to clinical science and outcomes.The majority of articles focused either on anatomy and biomechanics of meniscal injury or prevention and physical rehabilitation (Figure 6), with both groups contributing 12 papers each.

We reviewed the first 321 results of the sorted list to eventually identify the 50 articles that pertained to the meniscal criteria (Figure 1).

There was a moderate and statistically significant positive correlation between year of publication and citation density (r = 0.625; P < .001), and little correlation with no statistical significance was found between year of publication and raw citation count (r = 0.241; P = .10) (Figure 2).
All articles were published between 1975 and 2013 (Figure 3), with most of the articles being published between 2000 to 2010 (n = 25 articles) and 1990 to 1999 (15 articles).

The majority of articles were published in The American Journal of Sports Medicine (AJSM), with 9 papers (18%), followed by Arthritis & Rheumatology and the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (JBJS; also known as the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery–American Volume), with 7 (14%) and 6 (12%) articles, respectively (Figure 4).
Most articles had a clinical science and outcome focus (n = 26; 52%), followed by basic science (n = 16; 32%), with only 6 (12%) reviews or meta-analyses (Figure 5).
The majority of articles focused either on anatomy and biomechanics of meniscal injury or prevention and physical rehabilitation (Figure 6), with both groups contributing 12 papers each.
